right.title: Which of the answers are not a React component's life cycle?
What does `useState` hook do?
right.right: Adds state to a functional component
right.a: Adds props to a functional component
right.b: Adds state to a functional component
right.c: Adds lifecycle methods to a functional component
right.d: Adds event listeners to a functional component

wrong.title: What is the purpose of `props` in React?
wrong.right: To pass data from a parent component to a child component
wrong.b: To pass data from a parent component to a child component

withoutAnswer.title: What does `useEffect` hook do?
withoutAnswer.right: Performs side effects in functional components
withoutAnswer.b: Performs side effects in functional components

right.title: What is the difference between `==` and `===` in JavaScript?
right.right: `===` checks for strict equality (value and type), `==` performs type coercion
right.a: `==` checks for strict equality, `===` performs type coercion
right.b: `===` checks for strict equality (value and type), `==` performs type coercion

wrong.title: What is hoisting in JavaScript?
wrong.right: The behavior where variables and function declarations are moved to the top of their scope
wrong.a: A way to optimize JavaScript code
wrong.b: The behavior where variables and function declarations are moved to the top of their scope
wrong.c: A type of error in JavaScript

withoutAnswer.title: What is a closure in JavaScript?
withoutAnswer.right: A function that has access to variables from its surrounding scope even after that scope has finished executing
withoutAnswer.b: A function that has access to variables from its surrounding scope even after that scope has finished executing

questions.title: Which of the answers are not a React component's life cycle?
questions.right: Initialization
questions.b: Initialization

questions.title: What is JSX?
questions.right: A syntax extension to JavaScript
questions.b: A syntax extension to JavaScript

questions.title: What does `useState` hook do?
questions.right: Adds state to a functional component
questions.a: Adds props to a functional component
questions.b: Adds state to a functional component
questions.c: Adds lifecycle methods to a functional component
questions.d: Adds event listeners to a functional component

questions.title: What does `useEffect` hook do?
questions.right: Performs side effects in functional components
questions.b: Performs side effects in functional components

questions.title: What is the purpose of `props` in React?
questions.right: To pass data from a parent component to a child component
questions.b: To pass data from a parent component to a child component

questions.title: What is the difference between `state` and `props`?
questions.right: State is internal to a component, props are external
questions.a: State is immutable, props are mutable
questions.b: State is external to a component, props are internal
questions.c: State is for styling, props are for data
questions.d: State is internal to a component, props are external

questions.title: How do you conditionally render elements in React?
questions.right: Using if statements or ternary operators
questions.b: Using if statements or ternary operators

questions.title: What is the role of keys in React lists?
questions.right: To help React identify which items have changed, added, or removed
questions.b: To help React identify which items have changed, added, or removed
questions.c: To add event listeners to list items
questions.d: To store data associated with list items

questions.title: How do you pass data down to child components?
questions.right: Through props
questions.b: Through props

questions.title: What is React Context API used for?
questions.right: To pass data through the component tree without prop drilling
questions.b: To pass data through the component tree without prop drilling

questions.title: What is a higher-order component (HOC)?
questions.right: A function that takes a component and returns a new enhanced component
questions.a: A component with multiple child components
questions.b: A function that takes a component and returns a new enhanced component
questions.c: A component that uses context API

questions.title: What is the purpose of `ref` in React?
questions.right: To directly access the DOM element
questions.b: To pass data to child components
questions.c: To directly access the DOM element

questions.title: What is virtual DOM?
questions.right: An in-memory representation of the actual DOM
questions.a: A faster version of the real DOM
questions.b: An in-memory representation of the actual DOM
questions.c: A way to style React components
questions.d: A way to handle events in React

questions.title: What is reconciliation in React?
questions.right: The process of updating the actual DOM efficiently
questions.b: The process of updating the actual DOM efficiently

questions.title: How do you prevent default behavior of an event?
questions.right: Using `event.preventDefault()`
questions.b: Using `event.preventDefault()`

questions.title: What is Fragment in React?
questions.right: A way to group elements without adding extra nodes to the DOM
questions.b: A way to group elements without adding extra nodes to the DOM

questions.title: What is the purpose of `React.StrictMode`?
questions.right: To highlight potential problems in your application
questions.b: To highlight potential problems in your application

questions.title: What is the difference between functional and class components?
questions.right: Functional components are simpler and use hooks, class components use lifecycle methods
questions.a: Functional components are faster, class components are slower
questions.b: Functional components use state, class components don't
questions.c: Functional components are legacy, class components are modern
questions.d: Functional components are simpler and use hooks, class components use lifecycle methods

questions.title: How to update state correctly in a React functional component?
questions.right: Using the setState function from useState hook
questions.b: Using the setState function from useState hook

questions.title: What is the difference between `==` and `===` in JavaScript?
questions.right: `===` checks for strict equality (value and type), `==` performs type coercion
questions.a: `==` checks for strict equality, `===` performs type coercion
questions.b: `===` checks for strict equality (value and type), `==` performs type coercion

questions.title: What is hoisting in JavaScript?
questions.right: The behavior where variables and function declarations are moved to the top of their scope
questions.a: A way to optimize JavaScript code
questions.b: The behavior where variables and function declarations are moved to the top of their scope
questions.c: A type of error in JavaScript

questions.title: What is a closure in JavaScript?
questions.right: A function that has access to variables from its surrounding scope even after that scope has finished executing
questions.b: A function that has access to variables from its surrounding scope even after that scope has finished executing

questions.title: What is the `this` keyword in JavaScript?
questions.right: It refers to the object that is executing the current function
questions.a: It always refers to the global object
questions.b: It refers to the object that is executing the current function
questions.c: It is a reserved keyword with no meaning
questions.d: It refers to the current function

questions.title: What is prototypal inheritance in JavaScript?
questions.right: Objects inherit properties and methods from their prototype object
questions.a: Objects inherit properties and methods from their parent class
questions.b: Objects inherit properties and methods from their prototype object

questions.title: What is the difference between `let`, `const`, and `var`?
questions.right: `let` and `const` are block-scoped, `var` is function-scoped
questions.b: `let` and `const` are function-scoped, `var` is block-scoped

questions.title: What is an asynchronous operation in JavaScript?
questions.right: An operation that doesn't block the execution of other code
questions.a: An operation that always completes immediately
questions.b: An operation that blocks the execution of other code
questions.c: An operation that is always synchronous
questions.d: An operation that doesn't block the execution of other code

questions.title: How do you handle asynchronous operations in JavaScript?
questions.right: Using promises or async/await
questions.b: Using promises or async/await

questions.title: What is a promise in JavaScript?
questions.right: An object representing the eventual completion (or failure) of an asynchronous operation
questions.b: An object representing the eventual completion (or failure) of an asynchronous operation

questions.title: What is async/await in JavaScript?
questions.right: A syntax for writing asynchronous code that makes it look and behave a bit more like synchronous code
questions.b: A syntax for writing asynchronous code that makes it look and behave a bit more like synchronous code

questions.title: What is JSON?
questions.right: JavaScript Object Notation, a lightweight data-interchange format
questions.b: A JavaScript Object Notation, a lightweight data-interchange format

questions.title: How do you parse JSON data in JavaScript?
questions.right: Using `JSON.parse()`
questions.b: Using `eval()`

questions.title: How do you stringify a JavaScript object into JSON?
questions.right: Using `JSON.stringify()`
questions.b: Using `toString()`

questions.title: What is the DOM (Document Object Model)?
questions.right: A programming interface for HTML and XML documents
questions.b: A programming interface for HTML and XML documents
questions.d: A way to style web pages

questions.title: How do you select elements in the DOM using JavaScript?
questions.right: Using methods like `getElementById`, `querySelector`, `querySelectorAll`
questions.b: Using methods like `getElementById`, `querySelector`, `querySelectorAll`

questions.title: What is an event listener in JavaScript?
questions.right: A function that is called when a specific event occurs on an element
questions.b: A function that is called when a specific event occurs on an element

questions.title: How do you add an event listener to an element?
questions.right: Using `addEventListener()`
questions.b: Using `addEventListener()`

questions.title: What is the difference between `setInterval` and `setTimeout`?
questions.right: `setInterval` repeatedly calls a function, `setTimeout` calls a function once after a delay
questions.a: `setInterval` calls a function once, `setTimeout` repeatedly calls a function
questions.b: `setInterval` and `setTimeout` are the same
questions.d: `setInterval` repeatedly calls a function, `setTimeout` calls a function once after a delay

questions.title: What is a callback function?
questions.right: A function passed as an argument to another function
questions.a: A function that always returns true
questions.b: A function that always returns false
questions.c: A function passed as an argument to another function
questions.d: A function that is never executed

questions.title: What is the purpose of `try...catch` in JavaScript?
questions.right: To handle errors gracefully and prevent the program from crashing
questions.b: To handle errors gracefully and prevent the program from crashing
